chapter.htmlHeader: What are the clinical features of cluster headache?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Cluster headache typically presents with unilateral peri-orbital pain associated with ipsilateral cranial autonomic symptoms (such as conjunctival injection, lacrimation and eyelid oedema).
    • The severity of attacks and quality of pain varies between people:
      • Pain is most often reported as sharp but may be described as pulsating, boring, burning, or pressure-like.
      • Attacks last between 15 and 180 minutes.
    • During an attack the person is characteristically restless or agitated, cannot lie still and may pace the floor.
    • Timing of attacks can often be predicted and may occur at the same time of night or day (circadian periodicity).
    • The person may identify a trigger for attacks, for example, alcohol, histamine, physical exertion, sleep or the smell of volatile substances such as perfume or petrol.
  • The International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD) includes the following diagnostic criteria for cluster headache:
    • At least five attacks of severe or very severe unilateral orbital, supraorbital and/or temporal pain lasting 15–180 minutes and
    • Headache associated with at least one of: ipsilateral conjunctival injection and/or lacrimation; nasal congestion and/or rhinorrhoea; eyelid oedema; forehead and facial sweating or flushing; a sensation of fullness in the ear; or miosis and/or ptosis; and/or a sense of restlessness or agitation.
    • Attacks occur between one every other day and eight per day for more than half of the time when the disorder is active.
    • The headache is not better accounted for by another ICHD-3 diagnosis.
  • The ICHD further categorizes cluster headache into episodic or chronic:
    • Episodic cluster headache (80–90% of cases)
      • Attacks occur in periods lasting from 7 days to 1 year and are separated by pain-free periods lasting at least 1 month.
      • Cluster periods usually last between 2 weeks and 3 months.
    • Chronic cluster headache (10–20% of cases)
      • Attacks occur for more than 1 year without remission, or with remission periods lasting less than 1 month.
      • Chronic cluster headache may arise de novo or evolve from episodic cluster headache.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The information on the clinical features of cluster headache is based on the clinical guidelines Headaches in over 12s: diagnosis and management (updated November 2015) [NICE, 2012], The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (beta version) [IHS, 2013], Diagnosis and treatment of headache [ICSI, 2013], and the European Headache Federation consensus on technical investigation for primary headache disorders [Mitsikostas, 2015], and expert opinion in review articles [Miller, 2013; Weaver-Agostoni, 2013; Hainer, 2013; Hale, 2014; Miller, 2016].
